summary: WorkflowClient.execute() and WorkflowHandle.execute() have inconsistent parameter ordering - client takes options first while handle takes workflow type first. The request is to standardize the signatures for better API consistency.
userImpact: Developers must remember different parameter orders when switching between WorkflowClient.execute() and WorkflowHandle.execute(), creating potential for confusion and errors.
rootCause: Design decision to embed workflow type and options in WorkflowHandle led to different execute() signatures between client and handle.
proposedFix: Two main proposals: (1) Pass arguments in an array: client.execute<T>('workflow', [arg1, arg2], options), or (2) Switch parameter order: client.execute<T>('workflow', options, arg1, arg2). Also suggested adding a variant that accepts a workflow function directly.
resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by standardizing the API to make WorkflowClient and WorkflowHandle signatures consistent.
keyQuote: WorkflowClient should use the same signature as WorkflowHandle.
